Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM images of (a,b) Bi2S3 and (c,d) the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid at different magnifications. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) XRD spectra of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid and Bi2S3 NW; (b) XPS spectra of the f-CNTs, Bi2S3 nanowires, and f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid; (c) FTIR spectra of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-hybrid coated linen fabric and bare linen fabric; (d) Raman spectra of the Bi2S3 nanowires, f-CNTs, and f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Tape adhesion test; (b) Electrical conductivity of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated linen fabric at different bending positions. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) Chemical stability test of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid using water and an electrolyte media; (b) Transmittance spectra of the solution before and after immersion of the catalyst. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 UV–vis absorbance spectral changes of the methylene blue dye monitored during the photocatalytic degradation by the addition of (a) f-CNTs, (b) Bi2S3 NWs, and (c) the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid in the dark and under illumination by a UV lamp (8 W) at different time intervals. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Change in color of the MB dye solution after 100 min of photocatalytic degradation. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Front (left) and back (right) views of the flexible photocatalyst before and after photocatalytic degradation. Department of Mechanical Engineering Hanyang University Haengdang-dong Seongdong-gu Seoul 133-791 South Korea Graphical abstract A unique metallic carbon hybrid film, synthesized with synchronized distribution of bismuth sulfide (Bi2S3) and exfoliated multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), has been proposed for use as freestanding textile electrodes in photo catalysts. The defect-rich morphology of Bi2S3 nanowire decorated MWCNT hybrid enhances the photocatalytic activity, electronic properties, cyclic stability, and electron pathways. The proposed f-CNT@Bi2S3-hybrid linen fabric electrode demonstrated a defect-rich morphology synchronized with high electrical conductivity. These properties greatly enhanced the photocatalytic activity and electron transfer. The high photocatalytic activity is attributed to the synergistic effect of the high electron affinity of MWCNTs and the structural distortion caused by Bi2S3 nanowires. Degradation of methylene blue dye was accelerated owing to the elevated activity of Bi2S3 nanowires, which provides fast absorption of contaminants and reduction of oxidative species. Our proposed system of metallic carbon freestanding textile electrode opens the broad applications of textile-based photochemical devices. Keywords Functionalized carbon nanotubes (f-CNTs) Bismuth sulfide nanowires (Bi2S3NWs) Carbon metallic films Textile fabric electrode Photo catalyst 1 Introduction Following rapid social and economic development, water pollution becomes an alarming concern due to its impact on human health and the environment. Various mitigation methods have been used to minimize water pollution, including adsorption [1] and coagulation [2]. However, these methods cannot remove pollutants in water thoroughly, and could produce secondary contaminants. Photo catalysis holds great promise as a solution to water pollution problems without producing secondary pollution [3]. Photo catalysts can thoroughly decompose contaminants with high efficiency and deactivate viruses in liquid. As is known, photo catalysts in powder form usually possess relatively high photocatalytic activity, due to their small size and large specific surface area. However, powders are difficult to recycle from suspension following a photocatalytic process, adding to secondary pollution and catalyst loss [4]. To use photo catalysts in practical applications, the photo catalysts need to be immobilized or coated onto a substrate. Textile fabrics are flexible materials, which are easily available, low in cost and possess considerable mechanical strength. In the past, textiles have been proven as a potential substrate material for wearable electronics when their insulating surface is made conductive. Likewise, the flexibility, low cost and easy availability of textile substrates would be beneficial in the field of photo catalysis also. Photo catalyst can convert light energy into chemical energy. This photo-induced process requires nanomaterials that absorb light and generate a transient state decaying at least in part to form some chemical species. Upon irradiation with energy photons with a higher band gap than the nanomaterial, charge separation occurs with the creation of electron hole in the valence band and an electron in the conduction band. This electron-hole pair can collapse by recombination, or can separate, forming an independent hole and electrons [5]. The most typical photo catalysts are semiconductor metal oxides, TiO2, and ZnO and carbon materials [6–9]. In the field of photo catalysis, utilization of carbon nanotube photo catalyst has been the focus of recent research. Applications of pristine carbon nanotube materials are restricted due to their low surface area and basal plane morphology. In the case of carbon nanotube material, the diffusion of electrons in the conduction band is usually slower due to low defect-rich density and basal plane morphology. The electrons, which are not immediately routed, can migrate to the surface of the carbon nanotube and there they are available for reaction with chemical species has been used. In this regard, metal sulfides or chalcogenides, a conjugated polymer in general, can be used as electron tunneling channels for electrons to increase electron diffusion in the conduction band of multi-walled carbon nanotubes. Metal sulfides usually exhibit a high photocatalytic activity and can be used as doping sites to increase the photo response of carbon nanotubes. For electrodes, Bi2S3 (mineral bismuthinite) has attracted considered attention for various potential applications such as photovoltaic, sensors, super capacitor, and lithium ion batteries. Due to its photoconductive, low band gap (Eg = 1.3 eV) [10], and its semi conductive properties; many efforts have been made for synthesizing Bi2S3 nanowires using solvothermal and hydrothermal decomposition, chemical vapor deposition, and solvent-less synthesis [11–15]. Despite various unique characteristics of Bi2S3, the use of elemental sulphur has many problems such as poor cyclic stability, corrosion with liquid media, poor electronic conductivity (5 × 10−30 S cm−1 at 298 K), and low ionic conductivity. To mitigate these drawbacks, various carbon materials, such as graphite [16–18], carbon black [19–21], carbon nanotubes [22–25] have been synthesized with various photocatalytic base materials. Carbon nanotubes are the best choice to assemble with Bi2S3 nanowires due to their unique electronic properties of the sp2 hybridized graphitic framework [26] and fast electron transport resulting from the coexistence of a tubular morphology and diffusive transport. CNT matrix holds tremendous mechanical strength, which is beneficial for the film formation. However, CNT applications in electronics are handicapped due to the absence of a band gap in this intrinsic material. The band gap of carbon nanotubes largely depends on defect-rich sites. Herein, we report the facile synthesis method of metallic film composite coated, moisture absorbent textile fabric; linen, electrode for efficient photocatalytic application. This study reports an optimal (1:0.8) composition of carbon nanotubes with a high surface area, low band gap, defect-rich Bi2S3 tunnels to extend the photo response in the visible region. The as-synthesized metallic films termed as f-CNT@Bi2S3 composite; coated linen fabric electrode demonstrates outstanding photocatalytic performance under UV irradiation, enabling photo-degradation of organic dye; methylene blue (MB). The textile photo catalyst showed excellent aqueous and electrolyte stability, and could be used multiple times without performance degradation. Most importantly, the simple fabrication method of f-CNT@Bi2S3 composite coated linen fabric electrode can provide new ways towards the fabrication of high-performance flexible photo catalyst and electrode materials. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Materials Plain-woven 100% linen fabric with 30 × 30 (Ne)/93/75 (per inch) construction was selected as the electrode material. For the synthesis of bismuth sulfide NWs, bismuth chloride (BiCl3) and thioacetamide (TAA) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. MWCNT powder (carbon content >90%, diameter 110–170 nm, length 5–9 μm, Sigma Aldrich Co.) was selected for formation of the conductive matrix. Nitric acid (60%, Matsunoen Chemicals) was used for functionalization of the MWCNTs. A carboxymethyl cellulose (sodium salt of MW 250,000 g) binder was used to prepare a thickened carbon paste. 2.2 Solution process synthesis of bismuth sulfide nanowires In this research, BiCl3 and TAA were carefully chosen as the basic ingredients for synthesis of bismuth sulfide nanowires (Bi2S3 NWs). The facile synthesis of Bi2S3 NWs was performed by a solution process method, as reported in our previous work [45]. In a typical synthesis, 0.1 M BiCl3 (1.5 g) and 0.3 M TAA (1.12 g) were mixed in 50 mL ethanol solvent. The subsequent mixture, dirt yellow in color, was sealed in a 50 mL Falcon tube and treated in a hot water bath at 70 °C for various periods. The processing time was optimized to ensure the synthesis of pure orthorhombic Bi2S3 NWs. Solution processing of the resultant mixture for up to 12 h ensued for synthesis of pure Bi2S3 NWs. At the end of the reaction, the black precipitation of Bi2S3 found at the bottom of the Falcon tube was collected and thoroughly washed with ethanol. Finally, the subsequent blackish brown mixture was dried under vacuum at 70 °C overnight. 2.3 Synthesis of CNTs decorated with bismuth sulfide hybrid (f-CNT@Bi2S3) Initially, the MWCNTs were functionalized to obtain reactive vacancies for Bi2S3. To introduce oxidative moieties onto the surface of the multi-walled carbon nanotubes and achieve greater dispersion, the carbon nanotubes were functionalized with acid prior to hybrid preparation. For this purpose, 2 g of MWCNTs was added to 100 mL of nitric acid. This mixture was sonicated for 2 h, with subsequent stirring for 8 h. Then, 500 mL of distilled water was added to the solution for the purpose of dilution. The resulting mixture was filtered and rinsed thrice via a vacuum filtration process to neutralize the pH. Finally, the carbon cake was dried at 70 °C under vacuum. These functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes were designated f-CNTs. In order to obtain the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid, the dried f-CNT cake and blackish-brown Bi2S3 powder were added to 50 mL of ethanol and continuously stirred for 2 h at room temperature. The homogeneous mixture obtained after stirring was filtered via vacuum filtration. The resultant dried cake was ground in a mortar with the gradual addition of 2% CMC solution to form a paste. 2.4 Fabrication of textile-structured photocatalyst Square pieces (6 × 6 cm2) of linen fabric were thoroughly washed in DI water at 80 °C for 5 min to remove any dust particles adhered onto the surface. The f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid paste was deposited on the linen fabric by the doctor blade method using 3 M tape. The coated fabric was initially air-dried at 50 °C followed by oven drying at 70 °C for 2 h. The fabric electrode was heated at 100 °C for 12 h and pressed at 150 °C in a hot press. The subsequent flexible electrode is termed the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid electrode. Fig. 1 illustrates the synthesis technique for fabrication of the linen fabric photocatalyst coated with f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid film. 2.5 Characterization and measurement Field-emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM; JEOL JSM-6700F) was conducted at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV to examine the surface and cross-sectional morphology of the coated textile substrate. Double-sided tape was used to adhere the samples onto the microscope stage. The samples were sputtered with platinum to avoid charging and achieve good electrical contact. Doping of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid was investigated via Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM; JEOL JEM-2100F) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Surface doping and chemical group analyses were conducted via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using the Multilab ESCA 2000 system VG from Thermo Scientific, USA, with an X-ray source of mono Al Kα with an energy step size of 0.05 eV. Information about the phase and crystallinity were attained by using X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectroscopy and was recorded on a Rigaku Denki X-ray generator (Rigaku, D/MAX-2500) using Cu Kα (λ = 1.58 Å) in the 2θ range of 10–80°. The X-ray generator was set to an acceleration voltage of 40 kV and a tube current of 60 mA. Structural analysis also was conducted by measuring the Raman spectra using a Raman microscopy system (NWS-3100, JASCO, Japan) with an excitation wavelength of 532 nm. Raman spectra were recorded in the range of 1000–4000 nm. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded by using the Nicolet™ iS™ 10 FTIR spectrometer from Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA, in the ATR mode. Porosity and surface area of the bare bismuth sulfide nanowires and f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid were determined via Perkin Elmer and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) data using a Quantachrome Autosorb-6 Sorption system. The photocatalytic activity of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 was measured using the extent of degradation of methylene blue dye. The UV–vis absorbance spectra for methylene blue dye were obtained via a UV-1650PC spectrophotometer (Shamadzu Co.) in the wavelength range of 220–240 nm. The standard four-point probe head system method (RM3000 resistivity test unit by Jandel Engineering, Switzerland) was used for measuring the electrical conductivity of electrodes. The scotch tape test was performed to ensure firm binding of f-CNT@Bi2S3 with the fabric. In this test, scotch tape was placed on the fabric and removed and then detachment of the conductive layer was examined. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Choice of material The outstanding performance of textiles in electronic devices led to the idea of producing a textile-based flexible photocatalysts for efficient photocatalytic application in this research. Linen, a natural cellulosic fabric, was selected, owing to its high mechanical strength amongst natural fibers, indicating its long-lasting properties. In addition, linen fabric is also known to gain strength when wet. Thus, photocatalyst-coated linen fabric, when immersed in any solvent, will not degrade easily, assuring high stability of the textile-based photocatalyst will be ensured. In the case of carbon nanotube materials, the diffusion of electrons in the conduction band is usually slower, due to the low defect-rich density and basal plane morphology. The electrons, which were not immediately routed, can migrate to the surface of the carbon nanotubes, where they are available for reaction with chemical species. Based on this, Bi2S3 metal chalcogenide was used to provide tunneling channels for electrons in order to increase the electron diffusion in the conduction band of MWCNTs. Metal chalcogenides usually exhibit high initial photocatalytic activity and can be used as doping sites to increase the photoresponse of the carbon nanotubes. 3.2 Morphological and structural analysis of the fabric electrode coated with f-CNT@Bi2S3 Durability and chemical stability are key criteria for photocatalyst electrode material. Physical bonding of the conductive coating on the fabric substrate plays an important role in enhancing its photoresponse chemical durability. In this regard, our proposed electrode of f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated linen fabric was observed via a video electron microscope (×40) and compared with bare linen fabric. From the Fig. 2 micrographs, the f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated fabric demonstrated seamless and uniform deposition of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 film. Neither cracked surfaces nor broken layer was observed. The crack-free coating of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 completely filled the weave-structured fabric because of the highly absorbent nature of linen fibers. Successful adhesion of conductive coating leads to high hydrophilicity and a subsequently high chemical reactivity. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) was conducted to analyze the morphology of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated fabric. The FE-SEM analysis demonstrated the even deposition of f-CNT@Bi2S3 on the linen substrate (Fig. 3 a). A cross-sectional view revealed a thick coating of the hybrid on the surface of the flexible linen electrode. The smooth and hydrophilic surface was easily coated with the hybrid paste, resulting in a crack-free and uniform coating on the linen fabric substrate. The layer was maintained at a 20 μm thickness to optimize the conductivity and photocatalytic activity of the fabric electrode system. It was observed that our suggested system of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 coating will not affect the flexibility and bending of the fabric substrate. Furthermore, with higher magnification, a rod-shaped pattern of Bi2S3 nanowires with varying length and diameter (∼1 mm and ∼90 nm, respectively) was observed (Fig. 3b). Additionally, a bamboo-like amorphous and defect-rich carbon nanotube matrix was revealed, which demonstrated intertwined tubular morphology (Fig. 3c). The intertwined structure of acid-treated MWCNT is due to the introduction of carboxyl groups onto the sidewalls, which provides a low aggregated surface. The resultant flexible and conductive hybrid film exhibited various properties, including optimal photocatalytic activity, porosity, and high conductivity, owing to the synergistic effect of the MWCNTs and bismuth sulfide. Fig. 3d–e exhibits the co-existence of two different morphologies consisting of acid-treated MWCNTs and solution-processed Bi2S3 NWs. It can be clearly seen that the Bi2S3 NWs were closely decorated with the conductive network of the MWCNTs. The defect-rich bismuth sulfide nanowires incorporated with the MWCNT network provided a fast electron transport mechanism. A digital image of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated linen fabric is shown in Fig. 3f. Fig. S1 (Supporting information) demonstrates the elemental analysis (EDS) of the Bi2S3 NWs, f-CNTs, and f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid. Successful doping of sulfur and bismuth groups was found. High contents of sulfur and bismuth metal groups provide high tunneling to f-CNTs for high charge induction and catalytic reactions. The significant stacking of highly exfoliated Bi2S3 nanowires onto MWCNTs may increase the surface area of the hybrid structure and subsequently catalytic reactions. To investigate the evidence of Bi2S3 decoration on f-CNTs, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used. To discover the variations in structural morphological characteristic, samples of bare Bi2S3 nanowires, f-CNTs, and the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid were investigated. Fig. 4 a shows the TEM image of solution-processed Bi2S3 nanowires, revealing a clear lattice fringe spacing of 0.33 nm, which corresponds to the orthorhombic phase of Bi2S3. A typical TEM image (Fig. 4b) illustrates the defect-rich MWCNT hollow tube pattern that provides evidence of covalent functionalization. Moreover, Fig. 4c–d clearly shows the decoration of Bi2S3 NWs on the tubular structure of the covalent functionalized MWCNTs. The as-synthesized f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid displays a coaxial structure with a clear lattice fringe spacing of 0.39 nm. The functionalized and defect-rich surface pattern of the MWCNTs provides swift accessibility for Bi2S3 nanowires to accommodate and subsequently provide fast electron transport in the conduction band of the MWCNTs. In this way, the high photocatalytic response was achieved. Structural analysis of our proposed system with f-CNT@ Bi2S3-hybrid coating was analyzed via XRD, XPS, FTIR, and Raman spectroscopy techniques. X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectroscopy was used to study the crystalline phases of the bare Bi2S3 NW and f-CNT@Bi2S3-hybrid film electrodes. Fig. 5 a demonstrates the X-ray diffraction pattern of the bare Bi2S3 NWs, disclosing several diffraction peaks at 22.4° (2 2 0), 23.69° (1 0 1), 24.9° (1 3 0), 27.4° (0 2 1), 28.6° (2 1 1), 31.78° (2 2 1), 33.8° (3 1 1), 35.6° (2 4 0), 39.1° (0 4 1), 39.9° (1 4 1), 42.5° (4 2 1), 45.45° (0 0 2), 46.4° (4 3 1), 47.1° (5 0 1), and 48.39° (1 5 1). These peaks indicate the presence of typical orthorhombic phase Bi2S3, with lattice parameters of a = 11.17 Å, b = 11.31 Å, and c = 3.99 Å, corresponding to the standard pattern of Bi2S3 in the literature (JCPDS no. 17-0320) [46]. No obvious characteristic peaks of other impurities were identified in the sample, indicating the purity of Bi2S3 NWs produced by the solution process method, whereas the XRD pattern of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid film disclosed two additional peaks centered at 25.8° and a small peak at 43°. The peak at 25.8° indexed to (0 0 2) diffraction intensity, indicating a graphitic tubular structure, and a peak observed at 43°, which is also a characteristic reflection of carbon nanotubes from (1 0 1) diffraction intensity [47]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed to infer the elemental bindings and chemical and electronic states of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid film. For clear elemental doping, XPS analysis of the f-CNTs, Bi2S3 nanowires, and f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid was performed. From Fig. 5b, it can be clearly seen that there is a high density of Bi2S3 nanowires accumulated on the f-CNT surface, with various bismuth and sulfur peaks in the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid. Fig. S2 (Supporting information) shows the deconvoluted spectra of the C1s, O1s, Bi4f, and S2s. The individual XPS spectra provide detailed observation of the chemical and electronic states of bonding in the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid. C1s peak demonstrates the presence of covalent functionalized carbon centered at 284.6 eV. The peak at 285 eV indicates the presence of sp3-hybridized carbon atoms. The deconvoluted C1s spectrum shows various oxygen groups due to acid treatment. The peaks at 286, 287, and 290 eV are attributed to CO (alcohols, ethers), CO (ketones, aldehydes), and COO (carboxylic acids, esters), respectively [48,49]. The O1s spectrum could be assimilated into two different peaks with binding energies of 531.8 and 533.9 eV, originating from oxygen atoms bound to carbon atoms in functional groups such as alcohols (COH) and carboxylic acids (COOH), respectively [50]. Therefore, oxygen groups in the hybrid film will contribute to the improved chemical reactivity in the presence of induced photons. The XPS spectrum of the bare Bi2S3 NWs showed two peaks at 158.5 eV and 163.6 eV, which corresponded to the Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 peaks of the Bi3+ oxidation state, respectively. Another peak, centered at 160.9 eV, appeared, corresponding to S2p with S−2 oxidation states. Additionally, the peak at 225.6 eV could be assigned to S2s. FTIR spectroscopy was used to characterize the chemical attachment of the f-CNT@ Bi2S3 on the linen fabric. The linen fabric was observed before and after deposition of the hybrid layer. The FTIR spectra were recorded in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. All the characteristic bands for the linen fabric can be seen in both spectra (Fig. 5c). The intense absorption peak observed at 3352 cm−1 was attributed to the OH stretching vibrations of cellulose. CH stretching vibrations of methyl, methoxy, and methylene groups, corresponding to the carbon chain of cellulose, were represented by the peak observed at 2906 cm−1. The peak observed at 1638 cm−1 could be attributable to the CC stretching due to the presence of aromatic rings. The band around 1440 cm−1 could be ascribed to aliphatic and aromatic groups in the plane deformation vibrations of methyl and methylene groups. The band around 1084 cm−1 denoted CO stretching vibrations of alcohols. These assignments were in agreement with those reported earlier for cellulose-based textile materials [51]. However, there were no noteworthy changes in the FTIR spectra of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated linen fabric. This indicates that only physical bonding of the hybrid is involved in the suggested fabric electrode system. The structural distortion required to enhance the photocatalytic response of the hybrid was characterized through Raman spectroscopy. For this purpose, the crystalline and defect-rich morphologies of the f-CNTs, Bi2S3 NWs, and optimized f-CNT@Bi2S3 were investigated. The Raman spectrum of the Bi2S3 NWs showed different vibration modes (Fig. 5d). The vibration mode at 142 cm−1 can be attributed to the n4 mode (antisymmetric bending vibration E) of the BiS3 group in the Bi2S3 nanowires, specified as the surface phonon modes. The broad peak was assigned at 235 cm−1, owing to the vibration modes of the Bi-S bond, which is in agreement with the reported Bi2S3 value. Moreover, the peak at 255 cm−1 corresponds to the n3 mode of the BiS3 group (antisymmetric stretching vibration E) of the Bi2S3 nanorods [52]. Additionally, another peak, observed at 302 cm−1, can be assigned to the n1 mode (symmetric stretching vibration A1), whereas the Raman spectrum of the carbon-based hybrid shows two distinct bands at shifts of 1338 cm−1 and 1575 cm−1, ascribed to D and G bands, respectively. The D band is attributed to the defects in the hybrid structure due to the A1g breathing mode of sp3-disordered carbon, whereas the G band corresponds to the E2g mode of phonon vibrations in sp2-bonded carbon atoms [53]. Yet, the frequencies of both bands were identical in the acid-modified MWCNTs and f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid, respectively. However, an increased intensity ratio (ID/IG = 1.07) suggested the defect-rich morphology associated with the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid electrode. Structural properties such as specific surface area, micropore volume, total pore volume, and pore diameter were obtained from the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms that are shown in Fig. S3 (Supporting information). Surface area and pore size characteristics of the Bi2S3 NWs and f-CNT@Bi2S3 are listed in Table S1 (Supporting information). As shown in Fig. S3, both materials exhibited type-IV isotherms with hysteresis according to the IUPAC classification, indicating the existence of abundant mesoporous structures in the hybrid material [54]. Based on the hysteresis loop in the adsorption-desorption isotherm, the BET specific surface areas of the Bi2S3 NWs and f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid were 10.11 m2/g and 22.93 m2/g, respectively. The increase in the surface area was mainly due to the incorporation of acid-treated MWCNTs and deposition of Bi2S3 NWs. Based on the N2 desorption curve and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method, the average pore diameter of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid was found to be 17.74 nm, corresponding to a mesoporous type [55]. 3.3 Physical and chemical durability of f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid Photocatalytic response of textile electrodes is associated with their physical and chemical stabilities. Mechanical stability under various stresses is also an important factor affecting the reliability and end use of flexible photocatalysts. Therefore, in this research, the mechanical stability and durability of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 catalyst on the linen fabric was investigated using the tape adhesion test, the electronic stability at various bending positions, and the chemical stability in solution media. The adhesion to the substrate of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 catalyst on the linen fabric was tested by the scotch tape test method using 3 M tape, as shown in Fig. 6 . The experimental results showed excellent bonding strength between the linen fabric substrate and the as-prepared f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid structure. No observable residues of the layer had been detached by the tape. The superior adhesion of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 catalyst on the linen fabric was achieved because of the extreme hydrophilic nature of the linen fabric. Thus, the results suggest that the f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated linen fabric has potential application as a highly durable photocatalyst electrode material. To investigate the mechanical durability of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 catalyst on the linen fabric, the textile substrate coated with the conductive layer was bent to different positions. A customized two-probe device with side clamps was used to measure the sheet resistance of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated electrode at different bending positions. A 2 × 5 cm2 sample of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-coated linen fabric was clamped in the side clamps and gradually bent to eight different positions. Surprisingly, the uniform coating of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 did not crack with such bending. The sheet resistance of the coated linen fabric was measured at all the bending positions. The overall change in the sheet resistance was only 5%, with no visible cracks appearing on the coating, ensuring high mechanical durability of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 film. The chemical durability of our proposed f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid was analyzed via the solution (water and electrolyte) immersion technique with respect to time (Fig. 7 a). To assess the stability of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 catalyst, the linen fabric with conductive coating was immersed in water and an iodide-based electrolyte and assessed over several dipping cycles. The electrolyte solution was composed of 0.5 M TBP, 0.05 M I2, 0.16 M BMII, and 0.1 M LiI mixed in acetonitrile, a solution generally used in battery, capacitor, and solar-cell devices. UV–vis spectroscopy was used to analyze the transmittance spectra of the water and the electrolyte solution before and after immersion of the electrode for a week. No significant change in the transmittance percentage of the electrolyte was observed, as shown in Fig. 7b. The transmittance spectra of the electrolyte solution and clear water, even after several dipping cycles, demonstrates that conductive linen fabric can be used as a durable electrode and photocatalytic material. 3.4 Photocatalytic response of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid The photocatalytic activity of the as-obtained f-CNT@Bi2S3 was evaluated by monitoring the photodegradation of methylene blue (MB) dye under UV light irradiation at different time intervals. Prior to the photocatalytic test runs, the adsorption in dark was examined by stirring the dye solution at 200 rpm for 20 min. After that, UV lamps (4 × 12 W, Phillips) were turned on for the irradiation. The photocatalytic activities were evaluated from the variation in the color of the reaction system by measuring the maximum absorbance intensity of the MB chromophore group at λ = 664 nm and λ = 291 nm. The time course of photocatalytic reaction of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid relative to the f-CNTs and Bi2S3 nanowires is shown in Fig. 8 . Among the f-CNTs, Bi2S3 nanowires, and f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid, the hybrid exhibited the highest photocatalytic activity, as Bi2S3 nanowire loading onto f-CNTs increases the photocatalytic response. The photocatalytic activity of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 being the highest is attributed to the collective effect of the (a) hollow CNT interior and (b) high specific surface area, from the Bi2S3 nanowire loading for better adsorption of the methylene dye, and to the (c) functionalized CNT walls favoring quick diffusion of charge carriers at their surface. Interfacial charge migration is a key factor in deciding the photocatalytic activity of a catalyst. Owing to the large surface area of Bi2S3 nanowires and the absorbent characteristics of f-CNTs, high absorption of dye impurities can be expected under dark conditions. The performance was further catalyzed by illumination under visible light. The high photocatalytic activity of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid was ascribed to the better defect-rich morphology with higher conductivity. This improvement may enhance surface charge induction and reduce recombination of excited charge carriers, thus exhibiting higher photocatalytic response. Furthermore, the low Fermi level position of f-CNTs than of Bi2S3 also favors photo excited electron transfer from the conduction band of CNTs to the Bi2S3 co-catalyst, which can easily reduce the oxidative radicals at the hybrid-solution catalytic interference. Consequently, the photo-produced holes in the valence band of CNT can now easily oxidize the adsorbed molecules directly or produce oxidative hydroxyl radicals, enhancing the photocatalytic activity of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid. Experimental analysis showed the significant degradation of MB dye occurred over time in the presence of f-CNT@Bi2S3 (Fig. 8c). The absorption band intensities of the dye steadily decreased with illumination time. These experimental outcomes indicate that the f-CNT@Bi2S3 catalyst significantly degraded the dye. After 100 min, the photocatalytic degradation of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid was 66%. These results indicate abundant degradation of the MB dye under UV light irradiation in the presence of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 catalyst. However, the Bi2S3 nanowires and f-CNTs under the same reaction conditions only removed 53% and 46% of the MB dye, respectively, indicating relatively poor photocatalytic activity. The high photocatalytic activity of the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid may be ascribed to the larger surface area of f-CNT@Bi2S3, which results in effective separation of photo excited e− and h+ [31]. Fig. 9 illustrates the degree of dye degradation over 100 min by means of our proposed system using a linen-fabric flexible photo catalyst coated with the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid. Additionally, the durability of the flexible photocatalyst coated with the f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid films was observed. Fig. 10 shows the front and back views of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-hybrid-coated flexible photocatalyst before and after the photocatalytic activity assessment. No difference was found in the appearance of the f-CNT@Bi2S3-hybrid-coated flexible photocatalyst, even after 100 min of photocatalytic degradation. This confirms the long-term stability and durability of our suggested flexible photocatalyst. 4 Conclusion A highly durable textile-structured photocatalyst electrode material was fabricated by using a functionalized carbon nanotube matrix and Bi2S3 nanowires. Structural and morphological analyses illustrated that the synthesized f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid possesses a porous structure with large surface area, high pore volume, and high electrical conductivity. The BET analysis further confirmed the surface area and porous characteristics of the photocatalytic hybrid material. The photocatalytic performance showed that, after Bi2S3 doping on f-CNTs, there is a rapid response in methylene blue dye degradation. The chemical stability of our proposed system of a textile-based photocatalyst demonstrates that, in comparison to f-CNTs, f-CNT@Bi2S3 possesses high electron diffusion owing to its large surface area and high electrical conductivity synchronized by surface doping of Bi2S3 nanowires. A highly conductive hollow interior with defect-rich surface morphology quickly reduced the oxidative moieties present in methylene blue dye. In this way, our suggested system of a textile-based photocatalyst provides new avenues towards the fabrication of highly photcatalytic materials. coredata.dc:description: A unique metallic carbon hybrid film, synthesized with synchronized distribution of bismuth sulfide (Bi2S3) and exfoliated multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), has been proposed for use as freestanding textile electrodes in photo catalysts. The defect-rich morphology of Bi2S3 nanowire decorated MWCNT hybrid enhances the photocatalytic activity, electronic properties, cyclic stability, and electron pathways. The proposed f-CNT@Bi2S3-hybrid linen fabric electrode demonstrated a defect-rich morphology synchronized with high electrical conductivity. These properties greatly enhanced the photocatalytic activity and electron transfer. The high photocatalytic activity is attributed to the synergistic effect of the high electron affinity of MWCNTs and the structural distortion caused by Bi2S3 nanowires. Degradation of methylene blue dye was accelerated owing to the elevated activity of Bi2S3 nanowires, which provides fast absorption of contaminants and reduction of oxidative species. Our proposed system of metallic carbon freestanding textile electrode opens the broad applications of textile-based photochemical devices.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of solution processed f-CNT@Bi2S3 hybrid film coated linen fabric as a free-standing textile structured photo catalyst
